title: Eggplant with Garlic Sauce
description: Tender pan-fried eggplant tossed in a pungent, savory garlic sauce with a touch of soy and rice vinegar. Quick to make, it balances silky texture with bright tang and a hint of heat for a satisfying vegetarian main or side.

ingredients.display_name: Chinese/Aubergine eggplants (or globe eggplant), cut into 1-1.5 inch chunks
ingredients.notes: trim ends, cut into bite-sized pieces
mixed with a little water to make slurry

ingredients.display_name: scallions / green onions, sliced (white and green separated)
ingredients.notes: white parts for cooking, greens for garnish

ingredients.display_name: red chili flakes or thin fresh chili, optional
ingredients.notes: adjust for heat; omit for mild

steps.text: Prepare eggplant by trimming ends and cutting into 1-1.5 inch chunks. Sprinkle with a little salt and let sit in a colander for 10 minutes to draw out moisture; pat dry thoroughly with paper towel before cooking.

In a small bowl combine light soy, dark soy, rice vinegar, sugar, and water; stir until sugar dissolves and set aside. In a separate small cup mix cornstarch with a little cold water to form a smooth slurry.

Heat a large non-stick or stainless-steel skillet over medium-high heat until hot. Add half the vegetable oil and swirl to coat. Add eggplant in a single layer (work in batches if needed) and cook without stirring for 2-3 minutes until the undersides brown, then toss and continue frying until pieces are golden and mostly tender, about 6-8 minutes per batch. Transfer cooked eggplant to a plate.

Wipe skillet briefly if it is smoking excessively, return to medium heat and add remaining oil. Add minced garlic, minced ginger and the white parts of the scallions and saut√© for 30-45 seconds until fragrant but not browned. If using chili, add it now.
Pour the prepared sauce into the pan and bring to a gentle simmer. Add the cornstarch slurry while stirring to thicken; cook for 30-60 seconds until sauce becomes glossy and slightly thickened.
Return the fried eggplant to the pan and toss gently to coat with the sauce. Cook together for 1-2 minutes to allow flavors to meld and the eggplant to finish tendering.

Turn off heat, stir in toasted sesame oil, adjust seasoning with salt and pepper to taste. Transfer to a serving platter and garnish with sliced green parts of the scallions and optional extra chili or sesame seeds.
